Some notes! First: Falcon Heavy to LEO is indeed 30 tonnes, because as stated in the video, we quoted fully reusable, RTLS and droneship landing. The number you see on wikipedia (63,800 kg) is fully expendable. If you need a source on 30 to LEO here's Elon talking about it - https://t.co/xPA9bGiNB9 (Also backed up by a true physics simulation too)

Second: That said, YES, I did have an error! I swapped graphics out last minute and forgot to change the lbs conversion of OmegA. So, the kN's are still accurate but the translation to pounds is incorrect. That number should be 4.9 million lbs. The corrected slide is on my website: https://everydayastronaut.com/new-glenn-2018/

In the video is mentioned that the common bulkhead was first used on the Saturn rockets. I think it was earlier, in the Centaur upper stage. I read somewhere, that the first common bulkheads collapsed, as Nitrogen was used as an inert gas between the the upper and lower shells of the bulkhead. The neighbouring liquid Hydrogen was so cold that the Nitrogen froze, creating a vacuum which the bulkhead could not sustain. Later this was solved by using Helium as inert gas, which stays gaseous close to absolute zero temperatures.

I have looked at a lot of videos about colonizing the moon & Mars. And I haven't found any with my same ideas. I think we should set up a moon colony on earth. We should have inflatable domes, which we cover with 3D printers with simulated moon mortar. The domes should be connected to each other by inflatable tunnels covered with simulated moon mortar. There should be living quarters, hydroponic green houses, gardens with garden soil for recreational gardening, a 5 acre pasture with one inch of garden soil and one inch of grass turf, a park with artificial turf and with small sections of real grass turf, and maybe even a very small zoo. All the domes will have plastic floors so no water is lost. Condensation forming on the ceilings will be drained into the water supply. All the domes will be blown up with compressed air from earth and will have a refresh system, which will refresh the air and maintain the air pressure. Humidity, Temperature will be maintained by humidifiers, heaters, fans and coolers. Light will be provided by multi-color LEDs, mostly white. Power will be supplied at first by solar power, and later by nuclear or fusion power. All water will be re-cycled, almost zero loss of water. There will be a bull, a cow, two sheep, and two goats, two chickens, two turkeys, two fish, and two rabbits. There will also be pets, two dogs, two cats, two bunnies, etc. (and maybe a small zoo) All of this will be set up by astronauts and robots before the colonist arrive.

The first colonist will be 5 fathers and 5 mothers, and 90 babies. The parents will be good parents, gardeners, farmers, zoo keepers, teachers, etc.. During the first two years an exact duplicate facility will be built on the moon. When the babies are two years old, they will move to the moon and live on the moon. Or if it is proven that they will be too young to travel to the moon than the facility on earth will be added to, to accommodate 10 more parents and 90 more babies. The two year olds would move into the new addition. Every two years the facility will be either added to, or 100 people will move to the moon. This plan will allow the kids to grow up in the isolation of the colony, and will make it easier for them to live in the isolation of the colony on the moon. And will allow them to grow up on the moon and be better able to adjust to the lower gravity on the moon, although some artificial gravity maybe eventually provided. This artificial gravity will especially be good for the parents. The kids will have everything in the facility to keep them occupied and entertained. Also they could have some books, movies, games, etc., especially adapted for them, being careful not to give them anything that would make them feel isolated.

After 20 years there could be 2000 people living on the moon, most of whom grew up on the moon. This program could be speeded up so in 20 years there could be 4000, 6000, or 8000 people living on the moon.

This program could be simultaneously done to colonize Mars so we could have 2000 people on the Moon and Mars at the same time. For the moon we could send supplies every month, but for Mars we could only send supplies every 26 months. So I suggest we send 10, 20, or 30 rockets to Mars every 26 months all at the same time.

We could have several refueling stations along the way to mars and orbiting mars so rockets could refuel along the way to mars and right before landing on mars so the empty rocket would have enough fuel to take off again, refuel in space and return to Earth. Eventually the colonist could grow trees, bamboo, and other plants for raw materials that could be used for making things. Eventually the moon and Mars could export minerals or small expensive items that were assembled on the moon or Mars, like jewelry, iphones, iwatches, etc. Or grown on the moon like caviar, marijuana, etc.

Here’s my opinion : I agree that it’s fine to favor a specific space company of your choice. However, that does not mean you should openly dislike another. Space X is not better, NASA is not better, Blue Orion is not better, and etc. All of them have their pros and cons. A true space enthusiast knows this. The things these people are doing are incredible, and you should hate on them because you think one is better. If you think that way, your no space nerd. The space community is supposed to be one big group of people who want to discover, learn, and explore. The fact that all of these amazing up n coming space companies are around today, is amazing. As noted, Bezos has almost unlimited funds towards whatever goals he wishes to achieve, but he doesn't have unlimited creativity and willingness to take risks to carry us forward in spaceflight. The AF passed out a bunch of dollars to replace the Atlas engine, but that rather limited the field to ULA and whatever choice they made and that was BO's BE-4 engine. That meant that BO received the majority of development dollars for their engine, which was actually behind the Raptor in design and build. Both NASA and the AF have consistently offered around 40% more dollars to whatever competitor SpaceX had, for the same deliverable. This also ignored the fact that until New Glenn starts returning mass to Earth, SpaceX rockets are the only ones that offer down mass as well as up. In other words, hundreds of experiments would not have been possible because physical results could not be returned, discounting the tiny amount of return mass for the Soyuz. More money for less capability means that NASA and the AF put their thumb on the scale for contractors of the past, even when new competitors prove their worth. This has consistently meant that contracts have been awarded on a completely uncompetitive basis and we, the taxpayers get to pay to continue to support the contractors which have failed to provide any innovation in either capability or cost from decades of cost-plus contracts. Look at the SLS and Orion. They have taken forever and are costing billions of extra bucks for capabilities that will be mátched or surpassed by two other companies on fixed-price contracts, probably before the second SLS/Orion leaves the ground and maybe before the first. If we actually want a Moon base that can be sustained and then travel to Mars, this has to stop.

Landing on a moving ship is exactly the same as landing in a crosswind. You can use this to your advantage by sailing in the same direction and with the same velocity as the prevailing wind at the landing site. This will cancel out any wind onboard the ship. This way you don't have to compensate for any wind during the landing phase, just let the rocket drift along with the ship.

What is the true nature of the Saturn V and why has no engine ever been created again to equal the size of the Saturn V's F1 engines? In fact, why was the Saturn V -- and the F1 engine -- retired after proving to be the most reliable by far of any lifting platform, having taken men to the moon 7 times with a successful landing in 6 of 7 attempts? The Soviets by comparison failed in their attempt, in a close race, at least in terms of producing a rocket capable of the feat.

In fact, the N1 rocket of the Soviets was powered by a viable rocket engine -- unlike the F1 engines of the Saturn V which blew up repeatedly on the test stand. A makeshift arrangement was installed in the Saturn V which allowed it to achieve near Earth orbit. However, the rocket did not have the lifting capacity for a full fuel load and hardware to complete a moon mission. This is without regard to the many other insurmountable difficulties and discrepancies in the record that have been well documented in various books and forums.

In the end however, many people must believe what suits them and comforts them more than empirical evidence will do for them. Even in the world of science, we see that consensual agreement and the maintenance of established theories are more important than evidence that does not serve according to such needs -- as one example, the constant support for a singularity as the origin and starting point of the universe, for which we must neglect third grade math of distant objects while remaining enthralled by the fantasy of unproven concepts that exist because of an unproven theory dependent upon such notions as dark matter.

Rather than address new and more recent evidence, lets remain in support of career building, political concerns and the need to maintain scientific consensus over evidence -- in the illusion that we know something while losing our ability to question.

It's much easier to program a feedback loop guidance system if the landing platform has stable momentum. By moving as quickly as possible in a linear direction, you significantly rob nature of the opportunity to do sideways motions, so a moving ship is MUCH easier to land on than a "static" one, which would be bobbing all over the place mindlessly in the water.

I think your payload to orbit capabilities is flawed. Makes no difference whether the rocket is expended or reused as to how heavy a load it will put in orbit. Pay load is thrust, time of thrust and vehicle weight subtracted from gross vehicle weight. Payload requires X amount of thrust delivered for x amount of time to deliver it to orbit. Add to that the thrust and time to accelerate the delivery system as well. So weight of rocket fully fueled and loaded, a lighter delivery system will deliver a bigger payload than a heavier system with the same thrust/fuel use.
Since most of the fuel is used to launch the fuel, lighter hardware will launch the same load with less fuel. Or launch it faster with more thrust.

Good work with the rundown on specs! It's worth pointing out that Falcon Heavy is at a reusability disadvantage for a couple reasons, though. First, the core stage is only designed for 1 or 2 reflights due to its high-speed reentry. And residue from burning kerosene will make it tough to refly the B5 side boosters more than 10 times each.

So when it comes to launching and maintaining a 4000-satellite constellation in LEO, New Glenn is probably going to be more cost-effective than Falcon Heavy. And the competition could be so fierce that it forces SpaceX to downsize BFR and cut its capacity to LEO roughly in half.

Also, SLS and New Glenn's first flights might not be as far apart as you think. Depending on how well structural testing for the SLS core stage goes, EM-1 could fly in late 2020 or early 2021. But given BO's secrecy, there's still a good chance we'll have a target launch date announcement for SLS first, even if New Glenn launches first.

It seems to me that there are actually two different kinds of "heavy lift" vehicles: Long haul and short haul.

New Glenn is optimized for the short haul. It has two stages that can lift a heavy, bulky payload to LEO at low cost. Falcon Heavy has always been somewhat compromised for the short haul mission because of its 12-foot diameter. It can put a lot of mass in orbit, sure - but only if the payload is physically small enough to fit inside a Falcon 9 upper stage. New Glenn has a 23-foot diameter so it can handle really bulky payloads that wouldn't be able to fly on Falcon Heavy.

The real reason for the two extra cores on Falcon Heavy was always delta-v and the ability to use the upper stage as a high-energy transfer stage - in other words, a long haul where you use the extra lift for fuel instead of payload. Saturn V is a perfect example: It could get an enormous payload into LEO with just two stages (as with Skylab), but it could also get a considerable amount of payload to the Moon with three stages. So I can see New Glenn being the best option for bulky, short-haul payloads and FH being the best option for less bulky, long-haul payloads.

An often overlooked feat i think is navigating these landing ships.
The entire flight of the booster stage is just a few minutes, travelling hundreds of km over sea. This means you have to know almost perfectly where the booster will come down in advance. Error margin of maybe a few km, and no time to reposition your ship means splashdown for your booster if anything goes wrong.

I appreciate your attempt at staying neutral in the modern "rocket race", but let's be real. Comparing non-existent vehicles is simply arguing over which spreadsheet looks better. Many things are likely to change before these things actually fly. The Falcon went through generational changes at a phenomenal pace; upgrades were often made between launches, and even after payload contracts were secured on a booster. With real hardware flying, TODAY, SpaceX is obviously king, and will be for some time. BO's pace and press release schedule is glacial, but their technology looks promising, and their ULA engine contract is essential for both organizations (BO to be seen as a "real" rocket company, and ULA to get propulsive landing tech in their portfolio). I am all for competition and innovation.  Unfortunately, by the time New Glenn is up and running, Super Heavy Starship will also be flying, and will outclass and under-price everything else on the market, including the Falcon Heavy. Let Bezos build his toys for rich people tomorrow, SpaceX is out there putting in work and gobbling up the global launch market today. You come at the king, you best not miss.

More new and bigger rockets, more diversity in types of launch to orbit, and more competition in the orbital launch market is better.
Expensive expendable super-heavy rockets (SLS) have their place, which IMO is either putting really heavy things in LEO (ISS replacement?), less heavy things in Moon orbit (LOP-G), or probes into orbit around the outer planets (Europa Clipper).
Expensive but reusable super-heavy rockets (New Armstrong, BFR) may replace expendable rockets, but will likely be used to construct a lunar colony (probably New Armstrong), launch a mission to send humans to Mars and back (BFR), send components to Mars to set up a colony (BFR, maybe New Armstrong?), or be used to build an Aldrin Cycler (BFR and New Armstrong probably working together).
For the Aldrin Cycler, I could also see something like SLS Block II being used (liquid boosters to replace the SRB's, stretched 2nd stage using a J-2X, maybe a stretched core stage with RS-68's for more thrust).

Heck, I even want to see some of the stuff that nobody thinks will ever happen due to red tape, like Nuclear thermal rockets, fusion rockets (laser initiated ICF for a start) and that kind of stuff.
Even rockets that use a really tiny amount of antimatter! Such an engine would use antimatter to make a tiny amount of U235 split, which would release enough energy to start a fusion reaction, with the fusion reaction providing the majority of the power used for thrust. Pure antimatter rockets require too much antimatter to be feasible with the current theoretical production capacity for antimatter, and that's using the level of antimatter that could be produced if every single particle accelerator in the world was used only to produce antimatter (something on the order of a gram of anti-hydrogen per year, with everything running 24/7/365, and costing maybe 2.5 Trillion per microgram! I saw a figure of 25 billion per microgram of positrons, the antimatter version of the electron, so including the antiprotons might drive the cost up by a factor of 10 or more likely 100. I don't actually know the cost, I just know it's way too expensive even if we do something like putting gigantic solar powered particle accelerators in orbit of the Sun closer than Mercury's orbit).
However, I still think Orion drives and Nuclear salt-water rockets are too crazy to ever be used on anything that launches from earth or is constructed in Earth or Moon orbit, and I have my doubts that a Nuclear salt-water rocket could even be constructed knowing the current state of materials science (A NSWR is basically a continuously detonating nuclear bomb, and I think it's pretty obvious that that's basically impossible to contain).
Closed-cycle gas core "nuclear lightbulb" engines might be just within the bounds of possibility.

I think cost is so much more important than the other factors. There isn't a lot of business for launches of that size at a cost over 100 million dollars. Which means the Atlas will subsist on a few launches a year of guaranteed contracts with organizations that are looking for stability, and willing to over pay. On the other hand falcon heavy and new glenn are looking to cut costs so much that more business becomes available. As more companies can afford launches, and satellites can be manufactured less carefully and efficiently to cut costs.

These stats are relevant for comparing them in a drag race, but we don't really have the numbers to compare there competitiveness in the market. I think new glenn might end up with a lower cost per ton to orbit than falcon heavy, but it isn't coming online fast enough to dominate the market before the larger class of rockets blows it out of the water. I also think that there is a high chance the first launch is a catastrophic failure, and that people will be hesitant about flying it until its had 10 or so successful launches. All this means is that I think falcon heavy will probably be more profitable from its first launch to its last, but I suppose we all have different definition of what the king of heavy lift rockets means.

I understand your reluctance to engage in tribalism, as you call it. I think it's slightly disingenuous, however, to compare a rocket that hasn't flown (New Glenn) to rockets that have a proven track record of delivering supplies to the ISS or satellite payloads into orbit. New Glenn's capabilities are, with the exception of the 1st stage engine thrust figures, entirely speculative. There isn't a physical rocket yet - it's a little soon to be calling it the king of anything. We don't compare the 2018 Audi R8 to the 2055 Porche 987 because only one of those actually exists at present. In addition, cost and reliability are valid concerns that I would've imagined you'd cover in a video of this length. If you don't have data on price to compare, why make a video? That's the second most important factor after reliability. Likewise, SpaceX and ULA have high success rates that would be hard to replicate for a new entrant to the field.

On another mark, the comparison seems rather arbitrary when three of the five rockets haven't been produced yet, and there are two other, larger designs in development. Why include some untested rockets but not others? Especially as the ISL and the Super Heavy are more likely to reach operational status than Grumman's rocket. This video doesn't feel like an unbiased comparison, it feels like a fluff piece. Just an opinion.

Eventually rockets will max out at 500 tonnes payload capacity before they become too big.  We are about 1/3 below that payload limit for how big we can build a rocket.  What is needed is a discovery of a fundamentally different heavy lift rocket engine technology.  We just have not yet discovered yet despite all the new competing surface to orbit launch vehicles about to come into service.

The Saturn V is biggest baddiest rocket of all time. It was discontinued after only 13 launches. It no longer flies today because the Saturn V was uneconomic and there just weren't any payloads that needed that sort of lift. When evaluating a proposed rocket characteristics like thrust, size, lift and fairing capacity are all useful indicators. However what really counts is cost per pound, cost per launch and payload market size.

The launch industry is rather a small market. There is a saturation of old, new, proposed launchers that is not justified by the existing market. There will be a shake out and many of these rockets will fail on price terms.

SpaceX business plan is low price for a reliable medium and heavy lift provider. The Falcon Heavy has very few customers because there are so few payloads that need that lift capacity. It probably was not economic to develop.

The proposed BFR (Super Heavy / Starship) is being developed under the assumption that a fully reusable launcher will drop prices to space so low as to free pent up low cost demand. That is possible depending how low the price will end up.

The price to orbit for the New Glenn probably will be comparable with the Falcon Heavy. However, the Ariane V has had difficulty finding and timing two satellite launches at one time. There may not be enough payloads to keep both the New Glenn and Falcon Heavy in business. The BFR could very well drive down launch costs to such a level there only will be SpaceX left in the business.

Of course the ultimate class of rocket is one that is 100% reusabile and if SpaceX is successful in developing the BFR then they will able to offer not only the greatest capability but also the lowest price;  BFR could potentially launch multiple full sized satellites to geostationary orbit per launch.

I'm not confident at this point that the SLS will ever get off the ground. It seems to represent the same boondoggle the F-35 faced (~$1.5 TRILLION in development cost), as it's not being considered as a weapon or for "national security" at this time. Ars reported in 2017 that $.72 of every dollar is spent on overhead for the SLS. That needs to change. Also, the viability of the RS-25 Aerojet Rocketdyne motor recently suffered a setback on it's engine stand static fire test. These are roadblocks that may cause further government funding issues, citing the overruns that (eventually) pushed the F-35 into existence for far different reasons. I have much more enthusiasm (and confidence) for privately held companies achieving thier goals than government bodies achieving thier budgets. That said, I too am all for seeing different approaches in how to achieve reaching outer space with efficacy.

I hope it's successful first time out, I really do. But if they have to go through the same baptism of fire that most others have had to go through, it's going to be orders of magnitude more expensive.

Why A Moving Ship Is More Stable:
A ship moving even at low speed can use computer controlled stabilising fins to dampen out pitching, yaw, and rolling motion caused by heavy seas. A stationary platform cannot. It's also worth remembering that the Earth's surface is spinning quite fast anyway, so any point on the surface is already a moving target as far as the rocket is concerned. Though I'm curious how the ship (and the crew onboard?) will cope with bad landings and the rapid unscheduled disassembly that often follows. Fire onboard a ship is a BIG DEAL, even if you're surrounded by water.

So my question is whats the market like for any of these heavy lift rockets. Back when Falcon Heavy first launched I remember Elon mentioning that they had considered not finishing developing FH and moving right on to BFR, but they were hearing about enough of a market to go ahead and fully develop it. We all saw its mayden flight and I belive they have 2 more launches in the pipeline, one as soon as Q1 2019 but is their enough of a market for all these heavy lift rockets either online or coming online by 2021. From what I have heard we'll probably see an average of 2 FH launches per year. Especially with even larger rockets that shouldn't come too long after that of which are looking to Mars. Don't get me wrong all these rockets are awesome but is there going to be a market for all of them especially with FH and Delta 4 already flying. Now new markets could absolutely open up, possible private space stations "space hotels" or other ideas but is their enough interest for all these rockets. With FH being the budget heavy-lift rocket but with a minimal area in the fairing, Delta 4 being expensive but incredibly reliable, and eventually New Glenn with is huge fairing, where will Vulcan and OMEGA fit in? Theirs only so many large and heavy government or military satellites to go around which seems to be the current real heavy lift market. I wonder how many companies are out there looking to utilize these types of rockets in the future.

Hey, great video! Could you perhaps make a video sometime about the different landing techniques that SpaceX and Blue Origin use? SpaceX uses the 'hoverslam', ofcourse, which means that the rocket's velocity reaches zero at the exact moment that the legs hit the ground. Blue Origin, however, 'float' their rockets above the landing pad before touching down. I assume this is to do some last minute corrections and make sure they hit the pad spot on. This is probably also the reason that it's easier for BO to land their rockets on a moving ship. But surely this has to have an impact on fuel use, etc? Curious to know if you also noticed this and what you think about it. Keep up the good work!

I am FAR more confident that New Glenn will actually see the light of day than I am for "Heavy Starship" or BFR or whatever Musk is calling his vaporware contraption today. BFR faces MAJOR funding hurdles. Musk admitted that it will cost as much as $10 billion to create the thing, and to date he has only been able to raise $250 million. The Air Force recently refused to give him any money for it. Meanwhile, Blue Origin is getting a $1 billion per year "subsidy" from Jeff Bezos's pocket (he's running it like a hobby project), and will be getting massive funding from ULA as soon as the new rocket engines are finished. Not to mention all the money Blue Origin will be making from sales of New Glenn launches as soon as it is finished.
